div.p: I received your letter dated January 7th. I am very glad that you have accepted my just excuse and I willingly continue to remind you of those things you have entrusted to me. As for your apology to me for what you call persistence, it is nothing; for I greatly approve of your zeal and concern for the church of God, and I strongly urge you to persevere in it; for it is the duty of a shepherd to watch over the flock.
May God bless you and your labors. From Italy, nothing is heard about their preparations that I think concerns us.

They are fortifying maritime places because of the Turk, and the Venetians have gathered several thousand men in their dominion to equip a fleet, which they will launch as soon as the opportunity of time permits; the other Italians are doing the same; however, regarding the other borders of the region, nothing has been changed. They say not even one of the fathers remained in Trento.
I had intended to send you the decrees of the 3rd, 4th, and 9th sessions now; but due to a friend's error, I cannot do so; I will send them at the first opportunity.
I had already given the eighth to Mr. Fabricius to be transmitted to you.

I am sending a booklet by Johannes de Turrecremata. We hear that Ochino has gone to Poland; it is regrettable that he was unwilling to repent; may God convert all who resist the truth or destroy them if it is expedient for His glory. I grieve for the sake of that province, Poland I mean, which now may it not be the sink of all errors.
We have received grave news about the plague raging in the Palatinate; we must pray that God protects His church and delivers it from evil.
We here are free from that contagion; if it returns to us early this spring, may the Lord's will be done; in His hand is our life and death.
Blessed are the dead who die in the Lord.
Farewell, my lord, and pray to God for us.
They announce that the father has recovered.
Your most observant Ulisse Martinengo. To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, most upright pastor of the church of Zürich, his most esteemed lord. In Zürich.
Letters from the most illustrious Count of Barch, etc., to Bullinger.
